intro: Malva nicaeensis var. liocarpa, commonly known as the Nicaean mallow, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and broad, heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its fibrous roots and mucilage-rich tissues make it notable for its potential medicinal and industrial uses. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in open woodlands and rocky areas.
